project.name: Plugins: Executable WAR
project.description:
This plugin takes the host project's WAR artifact and produces an executable WAR file out of it. When executed, that WAR file will deploy itself and all other WAR files specified on the command line in an embedded Jetty server. The server will bootstrap a ComponentContainer and offer it as a parent container for the deployed web applications.
You configure the web server's classpath by a <dependencies> section in the plugin configuration of your host project. To use the default Jetty server bootstrap, add the following dependency to the plugin in your project:
<dependency> <groupId>org.fluidity.deployment</groupId> <artifactId>war-bootstrap-jetty-impl</artifactId> <version>${fluidity-version}</version> </dependency>
The plugin exports an org.fluidity.deployment.RuntimeControl component in the global ComponentContainer. That object can be used to programmatically stop the Jetty server started by this plugin. The server can also be stopped by pressing Ctrl-C.
You can implement your own server bootstrap with the web container of your choice by providing an implementation to the org.fluidity.deployment.ServerBootstrap interface from the org.fluidity.deployment:war-bootstrap-spi module and package it in a JAR file or, ideally, in a Maven module.
In case of a Maven module, the module may not depend on anything used by the WAR applications themselves because class incompatibilities are likely to occur due to different class loader domains. Moreover, any dependency of the Maven module that should not be visible to the deployed WAR applications must be declared optional in the POM.
You can then use the Maven module containing your own server bootstrap in place of the org.fluidity.deployment:war-bootstrap-jetty-impl dependency above.
